user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ResetState:
```c
void UT_ResetState(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    int32                i;

    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (FuncKey == 0 || StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }
    if (FuncKey == 0)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = 0;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UT_ResetState:
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
static void UT_ClearStubEntry(UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr)
{
    /* Be sure to call free() on any malloc'ed buffers before clearing */
    if ((StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER || StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER) &&
        StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr != NULL && (StubPtr->ModeFlags & UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) != 0)
    {
        free(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr);
    }
    memset(StubPtr, 0, sizeof(*StubPtr));
}
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static void UT_ClearStubEntry(UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr)
{
    /* Be sure to call free() on any malloc'ed buffers before clearing */
    if ((StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER || StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER) &&
        StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr != NULL && (StubPtr->ModeFlags & UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF) != 0)
    {
        free(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr);
    }
    memset(StubPtr, 0, sizeof(*StubPtr));
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. UT_ClearStubEntry takes a UT_StubTableEntry_t * and explicitly modifies the pointed object (calls free on an inner buffer and then memset to zero), so the pointer cannot be const-qualified. A violation would occur if the function only read the object but used a non-const pointer (e.g. a function that merely inspects StubPtr->EntryType but declares StubPtr as non-const), but that is not the case here.
